title: Jhin, the Six Million Gold Piece Man
body:

Honestly, if you were to look at Draven's abilities in a champion reveal without playing the character you'd probably be complaining about how boring he looked. Our game needs characters with varying degrees of accesibility.  It needs Garen and Sona types just as much as it needs Yasuo and Draven types.

While I won't attempt to speak for anybody else here, it seems that while a lot of people are citing their disappointment as "these abilities seem kind of similar to other abilities!" it's probably more likely that the disappointment is coming from said abilities not really seeming to be presented in a context that allows them to feel fresh. For example:

{{champion:223}} - Despite his Q being "just another skillshot with a slow", having it exist as part of An Acquired Taste's system (having it apply a stack, rewarding players with a stun if they've already applied 3) gives it a fresh new feel and new decisions to make. Even among other similar abilities tied to champions within Tahm's role, it's not like Braum's projectile because allies can't interact with its effects, it's not like Mundo's cleaver due to target selection (Mundo wants to hit healthier targets to optimize % current health damage), it's not like Olaf's axe because it's equally useful for chasing and fleeing rather than strongly preferring one over the other with an interactive minigame, it's not like Sion's shout because there's no reason to try to use it on things in front of your target, etc.; it's the decisions that surround these abilities that make them different, not the basic tooltips they're tied to.

Likewise, with 3-hit passives--hell, 3-hit passives that give the user a huge movespeed boost, even, or 3-hit passives that can be partially triggered with a boomeranging skillshot--Gnar's and Ekko's still feel substantially different due to the factors that surround their use. Whether that's attack range, what kind of damage they deal (Ekko's wants to nuke squishies, Gnar's is great for kiting bruisers with high HP but not much MR), whether or not they have an internal cooldown (Ekko wants to skirmish, Gnar wants to kite and flee and chase), and so on! 

My main worry with Jhin, though, is that from what I've seen, it doesn't feel like I'll really be having to make different decision with him compared to Cait, who was recently reworked. My main gameplay as him is still going to involve setting up traps in advance and responding to them with a narrow, long-ranged skillshot that I don't want other enemies to bodyblock; I'm still going to have a special attack that I want to hit a champion with, which I'll generate by attacking minions from safe range; I'm still going to want to either use a really long-range ult to finish people off or soften them up and hope people don't block my projectiles; I'm going to mainly focus on bullying my opponents with impressive range and positioning carefully due to my low mobility, but I'll still be able to distance myself a bit if I prepare for it, and so on. 

Strategically, as Jhin, I don't think I'd be able to bring anything to the team that Cait can't aside from some nitty-gritty specifics. "We want a really slow Marksman that can set up with traps, poke enemies down from range, throw a little CC in the mix, and pick off enemies with their ultimate if they just barely get away from the fight." Will the difference between the two really be that Cait provides her root with her trap and not by shooting someone immediately after they get slowed by her trap? That Jhin has to manually aim his ult and Cait doesn't? It doesn't seem like enough distinction to me, and I fear we're just going to get another Akali/Diana situation again--only one of the two will ever be played due to doing their thing better, and the other will sometimes be mentioned as a problem by devs on the forums.

Honestly, if you meant Jhin as I see him, then you did a good job. Maybe my mind is just a bit more twisted, but I DO see an artist in Jhin. He isn't just a brutish "marksman" who runs into the fray guns' a blazing, no, he is careful: methodical even. He lays down his traps like set pieces and then uses his abilities to make the subject of his art, "dance" to his rhythm. He is a mastermind, a virtuoso, using even the enemies play, their slightest tendencies to render his artistry. Seeing how they push, when they push, where they step when they run from a gank, their harassing patterns, andwhere they ward, he uses all of these things to plan the perfect scene for the pinnacle of his art and their perfect moment of beauty: Death.

Look at his Jihn's passive:

WHISPER: Jhin’s gun - Whisper - chambers four shots, the last of which always crits and applies extra damage based on a portion of his target’s missing health. After firing all four shots, Jhin takes a moment to reload.
Jhin’s crits deal less damage than normal, and his attack speed doesn’t actually scale with attack speed. Instead, Jhin gains attack damage from any attack speed and crit chance he earns through itemization and runes, while crits give him a burst of movement based on his attack speed.

He has a reload passive like Graves does, and seems to not be able to use attack speed at all (in the traditional sense). I'm curious to see if he reloads faster as the game progresses, or always at the same rate. Also curious if he gains traditional attack speed while leveling, or if his 4 shots always fire at the same rate.

I see a lot of champions recently who follow this pattern, and Jhin is partially guilty of this as well, though not as extreme as a few others: Here's one ability or passive that does this, this, _this_, is inhibited by this, but gives him this instead which does this to other people, and gives this buff.  That's over-dramatizing the situation, but it's something I don't believe is helping with either readability or accessibility, and instead creates the frustration you guys said you wanted to avoid.

Too much effort is being spent on making the champion look and feel cool without much thought going into what it's like to play with and against them, which is why I consider Jhin was _partially_ guilty seeing as he doesn't have mobility that puts Usain Bolt to shame. It strikes me as a company losing passion for the game itself and replacing it with a passion for the money it makes them.

And its a shame that the majority of the players are ignoring Riot taking this slippery slope and actually supporting them for it. 
Maplestory used to be massively popular, and they basically died after taking a similar turn. WoW used to be massively popular, and lost a huge following after taking a similar turn.

The people that just accept what they're doing are the ones allowing Riot to head down the same path. The people supporting them for doing it are the ones killing the game.

Creating content is good. You can praise them for that. Creating content with a blatant disregard for how it affects the game is a terrible, terrible mistake. You should not be white-knighting for Riot over that.
